Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course allowed me to expand upon many of the skills I learned in introductory microeconomics. Particularly, I learned about applying higher level math concepts to economic theories.
The Lagrangian method
I learned about optimization techniques, Slutsky equation, externalities, and much more.
nice
I didn't develop many skills at all, it was mostly repeating intro micro but with calculus. We learned how to take derivatives and set MC = MR ... many times.
Nothing. I learned nothing.
General Intermediate Micro Course
I learned how to solve more complex econ problems..
I learned how to apply mathematical models to economic theories.
Helped me develop my skills in the math behind economic theory.

This was mainly an introduction to multivariable calculus, and integrating it with the microeconomic concepts we learned in Intro Econ courses.  Course was taught in a comprehensive and clear way, it is just difficult to understand at first because many of the ideas are counterintuitive.
Basically the same as intro micro but with calculus
Nothing. We literally just spent the entire semester solving problem to mathematically prove and verify that competition leads to efficient outcomes

I developed a stronger quantitative foundation to my economics studies. The course surveys consumer and producer theory. It definitely hinges on a lot of math, but more conceptual game theory topics add a perfect complement.

I learned the nitty-gritty of microeconomics. It expanded on the connected learned in Intro Micro, as well as parts of Intermediate Macro. I did not, however, develop any cohesive structure of analysis or take-away, but rather learned how to maximize utility, consumption, trade, etc.
Some multi variable calc, the lagrange method in literally every possible context, substitutes/complements...it's exactly what you would expect taking a mandatory econ major class.
Basically intro micro, with some more complicated concepts and more math/calculus involved.

THE BEST PROFESSOR EVERshe is an amazing instructor and person. I'm interested in microeconomics so this was my next step in courses. I learned a lot about further and more complex problems in economics.
Micro concepts of supply and demand through math.
Learned how to take a Lagrangian and that's about it.
Basic microeconomics, algebra
learned how to take a multivariable derivative
Applying Calculus to Economic concepts.
Learned a lot about the basic modeling and math behind how businesses work, how pricing is done, how insurance works, and so forth!
Economics
I learned how to use calculus as a model for economics. I also deepened my understanding of consumer and firm behavior.
A deep understanding of lots of econ
I learned how to problem solve well.
How to view consumer service

I learned a lot about the mathematical modeling of systems in microeconomics. This course covers a lot of material on topics from optimization, labor, welfare, insurance, monopolies/perfect competition, and so forth. You get a chance to see the math that goes into the curves seen in intro classes.
Intermediate Microeconomics is a notoriously hard class in the Econ major. Evangelia Chalioti is a really great professor who made the class as easy as possible.
Conceptually this course is practically the same as intro micro, it's just that you're using calculus now.
The stuff we did in intro but more theoretical/with more math.
I learned in depth microeconomics
Very good class on microeconomics. Teaches all the concepts very well.

This class extended several concepts that were covered in intro microeconomics, like labor and production, monopolies, etc. and added a more rigorous mathematical foundation to them. In addition, we were able to cover some new aspects that I hadn't really considered in microeconomics before, such as welfare problems.

I basically learned the intro micro content, but with calculus. You will learn a lot about optimization (that is the main skill taught in the course). You will also learn some of the insights behind the optimization problems, but this class is certainly heavier on math.
This class provided me with wonderful insights that have helped me understand the power of social science. It has helped me become more analytical of the world around me.

While intro micro gave me a good understanding of what microeconomic theory is, intermediate gave me a solid foundation of tools to explain why we behave the way we do when we make economic decisions.
Essentially took a deeper dive into the topics taught in intro micro, with more of a mathematical lens.
Strong foundation in econ
Further developed economic intuition.

It was interesting to apply multivariable calculus topics and methods to real world problems.  I felt like I now understand the reasons why certain economic principles hold because we really focused on the math behind the ideas.
Learned mechanics behind why economics works the way it does, and problem solving skills within the field.
I learned the concepts in introductory microeconomics in great depth and from a mathematical perspective.
Very much furthered my knowledge of micro economic theory.
I learned more advanced models and concepts to describe microeconomic theory. I also trained my math abilities, particularly the ability to maximize or minimize a function given a constraint.
Essential microeconomics skills.
This class provided strong insights into the mathematical side of microeconomics.
Literally nothing. This class actually managed to teach me nothing in an entire semester.
The course was well developed and run. Honestly, I don't know if I'll use these skills that much in real life but it has made me think in different ways.
Intermediate Microeconomics

This is basically an extension of intro micro with some calculus thrown in. If you liked intro and you're good at math, you'll learn about a lot of topics more in-depth and the course won't feel too challenging,.
I really further developed my single variable calculus skills, along with my multi variable calculus skills.
I learned some multi-variable calculus and economics at an intermediate level.
I learned a lot about how to use mathematical techniques/methods to prove economic conclusion we learned in Intro Micro.
Basic tools for microeconomic analysis about the decisions of consumers, workers, and firms.
Lagrangian optimization in about 8 million different contexts
I learned about how markets work and how to mathematically derive the theorems we learn in intro.
Deepened what I learned in intro micro
Great course in Microeconomics. Must-take!
How to mathematically analyze consumers' and firms' decision making; a lot of the same concepts from intro micro, but with calculus to back it up.

I learned how to use the Lagrangian multiplier and apply economic principles to various different kinds of economic problems. Honestly, the course seemed repetitive after a whilemaximizing and minimizing equations for utility, expenditure, or profits, adjusting for intertemporal decisions or taxes, it started to feel like we werent learning anything really new. This course didnt feel inspiring, but I ended up with a solid grasp of several traditional methods of economic reasoning.
I learned then lagrange method and how to apply this to profit maximization.
I learned many different quantitative methods of getting to key questions about utility, costs, insurance, market structures and much much more.
Practically the entire basis for the economy

The course is a dismal weeder with little mask of being any else; its assumptions are not only abecedarian, but eschewed by the higher field in which the course would ostensibly place its survivors.  Tolerance for long, banal repetition of partial differential equations -- against economic theory, thoughtlessly in mimicry of TA-led 'blindly just do this' sections not every student can attend (and when PDEs aren't a technical prerequisite! gosh, sucks for those so trapped by this course that they'll never write a review, dropping halfway through !) -- is a skill the course hones.  The TAs cannot alone repair the teaching deficiency of the course, given its size and erratic organization -- and self-study is of little avail, as Eva rejects following any one textbook in remotely ordered ways.
The Lagrange and different ways to apply it
The economic concepts learned in introductory microeconomics were greatly expanded.
I built a stronger base of fundamental microeconomic knowledge.
You learn the Lagrange and connect all the graphs from intermediate micro to actual math.
Learned about microeconomics and analysis and Lagrange optimizations.

This course helped my quantitative skills, abstract thinking and teamwork. I was happy to start perceiving the world in terms of maximizable variables; I grew familiar with the lagrange maximizer method and applied it to a variety of scenarios. I also learned about the most efficient outcomes in markets.
The math basis for a lot of microeconomic theory.

The strengths of this course revolved mostly around the professor and the organization of the material. The passion of the professor really sparked an interest in economics in me, and I enjoyed going to class to see all of the connections not only within course material, but also to everyday life.
The course was a big lecture and felt like it. Even office hours would have more students than small lectures do. It was hard to ask questions.

The strength of this course came from Professor Chalioti and her TF's (Donghyuk). They did well at explaining the material. There is not much that can be improved as it is just another course in the Economics sequence.
a lot of weaknesses
I think that this course was incredibly difficult, and not taught to a caliber that could be followed. The teaching assistants were almost not helpful at all.

It's a pretty boring course and felt very redundant; we basically did the same process every class and acted surprised when we got the same result (set up Lagrange, take the derivative and set it equal to 0, derive MC = MR usually). A lot of that could be cut out for more interesting material or more insight/interesting examples we do cover. 

Also, the problem sets designed by the TAs were often vague, poorly phrased, or flawed, and that could be really frustrating. They should be more thoroughly vetted.

The main weakness of this class is that there is not enough practice material for exams. If the professor posted past exams, that would be extremely helpful for studying. Moreover, I understand that this is a department-wide policy, but the policy that only 1/6 people get A's is absurd. Based on the distribution of this class, you almost need 100% throughout the course to get an A.

Most people will agree intermediate micro is, by nature, just not really a good time overall. That said, Eva and the TAs really did try their best to make the class as accessible as possible, offering lots of office hours, homework/midterm solutions (post-submission), interspersing fun videos and "lighter" things in between the deep quantitative modeling, etc. That said, office hours/TAs were sometimes difficult to access on tough pset days, but I guess that's a nature of the class difficulty and tough pset weeks. Not sure how it could be further improved.
Nothing made sense. Explain things more clearly.

Pretty standard Econ lecture - not much to change
Although I did find it weird that they just gave everyone 100% on psets.
it is very hard to understand the lectures

The course moves at an appropriate pace and incorporates many current events. However, the level of difficulty of the PSETs is drastically different from the difficulty of lectures and exams. While the PSETs are interesting and engaging, they make it difficult to judge the standard of work that is expected from the course.
I think this course is a very strong course for sometimes dry material.
strengths: abundant TA and office hours available, helpful solutions posted after all psets are due, helpful material made available to prepare for midterms and final in advance

Professor is good but some of the TAs are definitely better than others - helps to shop around for TAs
The tests often felt like they tested your ability to do quick/accurate algebra rather than your knowledge of the economic concepts
Lectures never do examples and make the p sets really hard to complete. Need better advising!
I enjoyed that the problem sets were graded on effort. The exams were not, however.

Strength: it fulfilled a major requirement. Weakness: disparate material that does not come together to form a full structure. I did appreciate how the exams were very fair. If one studied a lot, one could likely do pretty well.

It's a hard class...lectures are long and hard to follow, but there really isn't much that can be done about that. Problem sets are long and they are graded extremely easily, which is somewhat annoying for the students who actually put in effort compared to others who just copy or leave problems blank.
Maybe offering more in terms of application / uses of the theory we're learning in actual economic research.
The class builds upon itself and is strongly analytical.
This class is hard. Not fun.

Everyone gets a 10 on the problem sets because they're graded fir completion, so the only think that ends up counting for your grade is the exams. Two midterms and a final, and her exams are pretty fair.

Strengths: Prof/TA's were all very nice people. Very clear on what would be expected of us on exams. Problem sets were extremely helpful in understanding the material.

Weaknesses: Lectures were painfully slow. Problem sets were graded "based on effort" (ie. everyone gets 100%), so the only materials that counted were exams.  No clear feedback and strange grading criteria.

The lectures were engaging and well taught but very fast. I did not like the TF sessions, as they were rarely useful and very boring. Prof Chalioti was the only person where it would be useful to go to her for help and her office hour times were limited (as there's only one of her so that's understandable) I just wish that the TF quality was higher so we didn't have to always rely on just the professor to get help outside of class times. 


PSETS seemed MUCH harder than any other materials that we would get during class, either during the lecture (i would be 100% on board with what was being taught in lecture but then have no idea how to even start a problem set problem) or during tests the PSETS ended up not being good resources to study from because their difficulty was so variable compared to the actual midterms/test which seem more ordinary and also based off of lecture. I appreciated them being GRADED on effort but I wish that there was some sort of additional feedback given when an answer clearly ended up being wrong etc. but I just wouldn't realize that because no one would correct my PSET and for awhile I assumed 10 = i did everything right rather than I did everything but could have been right or wrong.

strengths: organized fairly well, walkthroughs helpful
weaknesses: it only teaches the math behind econ, not the study of economics. I would want to learn why we make assumptions in economics, what impact it has, and how these models can be / cannot be applied to real world examples.
could be more interesting content-wise. I would like to see more of a narrative in class
I felt like the course worked through a lot of material, I know it's not the point of this course but it would be interesting to see some of how it might be applied.

The course went very fast, which is understandable because there is a lot of content. I think it could be improved if there were more practice problems. I think the p-sets are too hard which makes the students do the p-sets very blindly without really understanding the content. Had the practice problems been more similar to the slides from class, I think the performance of students would improve.
The course assumes knowledge of multivariate calculus which is not a prerequisite for the course.

Perhaps the curve could change depending on the grade distributions. It doesn't seem fair to only give A's to 16% of the class when much more than 16% of the class is within a few points of a each other at the top.
I think it is a math class and it is pretty bland but necessary
Pretty standard micro class. psets and tests extremely straightforward.

No big complaints, it has a reputation for being harder than it is. Tests are fair and cover what you learn in class. We got candy bars the last day so that was cool. And Eva always made sure we were "clear" and "all good."
The course is well taught, and the psets really help you learn the material, though they are difficult.
Lectures are well-taught. Could be made more difficult

I honestly think this class was incredibly well taught. The lectures were informative, concise, and Professor Chalioti really made an effort to liven up each class. Additionally, the team of TFs was great, and I felt like all the support I needed was really there to succeed in this class. Problem sets were not unreasonable, and were designed to help solidify our understanding of the course.
I sometimes felt like we were just doing endless basic math and it wasnt clear how it connected conceptually to economics
More reliable TF's who actually show up to office hours and more practice materials for exams

I thought the content of the course was interesting and challenging, but I would have liked to spend more time discussing the intuitive parts of the class. E.g. what does our calculation mean, how similar is it to real life, etc. 

The main strength of the class was that I really understood the math and become very skilled with Lagrangian, etc.
Professor and TFs were all really good. I think more discussions of how economics is applied in the real world would be helpful.
I would improve this course by either making the problem sets be graded on correctness instead of completion or by lifting the mandatory curve.

Strengths: well taught, professor actually does practice problems with you in class which helps a lot. 

Weakness: personally not my favorite subject so not always the most interesting to me.

Strength: style and clarity of teaching

Weaknesses: none
Overall I think the course is good.

Thought it was well organized, however, the first two midterms were too long to complete in a class period.  I felt like I understood the material and knew how to solve the problems but did not have the time to finish.

Professor Chalioti is very engaging and easy to listen to. Only real weakness was the lack of room available in our original classroom (LC 102), which was solved after the first couple weeks of the semester - I would recommend not using that room again though.
Narrow down the topics. We covered a lot of stuff that fully never showed up on an exam, and didnt seem important to the course. Its a very packed course.
The course is pretty well organized and taught which makes rather difficult material more easy to grasp. I cannot think of a way to improve the course given the same material that needs to be taught.
I liked the structure of the course.

This course is really well taught with Professor Chalioti. She teaches the material with a strong purpose of making sure everyone understands. The assessments are also very fair and reflect what has been taught in lecture and heavily reflects the psets.

Strengths -- Eva is kind and funny, Esteban the TA was excellent, exams are fair

Weaknesses -- Lectures do not teach anything, Eva is boring, the problem sets are very, very poorly written (unclear what the question is asking for)
It's really hard material, Eva is a great teacher I don't know how to make it better.
This was a solid class. Lecture didn't help as much as going over the psets did.

Eva is awesome! Lectures were generally pretty interesting and not too hard to grasp. There's a lot of resources available if you need help and office hours were particularly helpful to work on the psets. I would say that your TA can be a bit hit or miss so maybe try to shop around.
The lectures and assignments were very well structured. The one weakness is that sometimes the problem set material was not aligned with the lectures we were on.

I liked that we did problems in class by hand. Also, the problem sets were completed for completion which was great because I could still work hard at understanding the concept without the pressure of perfect accuracy.

The slides were helpful but she went through challenging concepts too fast and left those to the TAs (i.e. Slutsky's equation) and kept repeating easy concepts (i.e. risk).

We need more practice problems! Also, it was frustrating that this class was curved because everyone did too well leading almost to a downcurve. Students were separated by only a few points, usually attributable to simple errors rather than different levels of understanding the material. The exams tested more of my algebra than my understanding of economics.
I really appreciate how the PSET grading method encourage us to understand the material better and incentivizes us to learn, as well as how Eva walks us through problems in class.

The course covers the necessary bases for an economics degree. I think the course could be improved by creating a clearer structure for how to approach problems, that is, teaching specific methodologies for specific types of problems. What I feel happened in the course is that we were taught strategies for specific problems (as they were shown in lecture), but those strategies often were insufficient to solve problems in problem sets /exams. Also, there should be better coordination between TFs and the professor to ensure similar equation formats and similar notation are used. It is a small point but the differences can become confusing.

Strength - Professor Chalioti! And pretty clear slides
Weaknesses - TAs were lethargic and unhelpful
The concepts were very interesting, but it was easy to get lost in the math and lose sight of the bigger picture.

The course is a pretty standard mathematical proof of introductory micro. Its content is fine and the homework and tests were appropriate. What needs to be improved, however, is very simple. The problem sets, practice material, and exams need to be written in a way that the average student can understand. There were frequent problems with subject verb agreement, grammar, and variables that unnecessarily caused ridiculous problems. Additionally, the notation used was inconsistent and very bothersome.
The lecture was so large that no one was willing to ask questions.
This course is really good.

For what it is (basically intro micro + more math), I thought this course did the best it could. There were definitely times in lecture when she moved WAY too fast over some pretty complex math concepts (and then way too slow over pretty basic conceptual stuff) so I thought there could've been a better balance between those (e.g., more time on math, slightly less time on easy-to-grasp concepts). It was also frustrating that the level of difficulty on the problem sets was waaayyyy higher than anything we saw in lecture or on the exams--a better match up between those would be a huge improvement.

The lectures were often unstimulating and not very well organized (they sometimes felt like a waste of time). The problem sets were generally good though in preparation for the exams and in helping us learn how to tackle traditional problems, but there was no real incentive to do them because they were graded for completionthe only things that really mattered in this course were the midterms and final, which perhaps contributed to my lack of engagement.

The strengths of this course is how pleasant the professors was as a lecturer. With that being said, the teaching (both in lecture and section) was not particularly effective and often only reached about 10% of the class. The other percentage of the class were left feeling discouraged and defeated. I personally felt as though I had to teach myself and the TF team was not particularly helpful. There should have been a bit more coordination between TAs and emphasis on student comprehension.

The strengths were how well the material was covered in the short amount of time the class was in session. Professor Chalioti made things easy to understand in the time she was given to teach tedious and complicated concepts in class. Unfortunately, the class itself has too much material to cover in just one semester that makes it nearly impossible to have every method explained during class and takes a lot of time to learn on the student's own time, through no fault of the instructors.

strengths: great office hours. the TAs saw that we were making the effort to be there and learn the material, and so really walked us through the work, and the good part is that through that guidance I actually did learn and understand the material because we could ask questions along the way and go back and rework our problems, knowing we had it checked by the teachers
weaknesses: I honestly wish the problem sets could count more because I put so much work into them each week

A textbook could better explain the theory behind the incomprehensible, thoughtless exercises done on PowerPoint in this class --- but, unfortunately, no reliable textbook was used!  The lack of organization of the course prevents a student from learning it visually or pursuing it at a deeper level. There is no skill in its content -- the inexorably long psets, without sufficient in-class explanation and only 'just blindly do this' explanations of tired TAs who cannot singlehandedly repair the teaching deficits of the class, make this class simply a war of attrition. The impossible length of the midterm exams striate students in a way that has nothing to do with understanding (and rewarding those with rote tricks or cheats).
A good course considering the material is dry at times. Would be better with more videos/ changing the teaching style because it can be long.

The course is well organized and office hours are accessible. The problem sets, especially the first few, were very time-consuming. I think that problem sets should be graded based on correctness rather than effort so we can better gauge our progress and how much we grasp concepts
The class is hard, but it was taught well.  You had to really go to lecture to understand what was going on.  The first few P-Sets are way more challenging than the rest.

I thought the lectures were very good, and so were the support resources and the instructor's attitude. Some P-set questions were unprecedented but TA assistance made them doable. My only suggestion would be to widen the scope of some of the tests, as I spend a significant amount of time studying for material that was not evaluated. I love Professor Chalioti!
The course was pretty well organized for what it is, but it is a little difficult to foster engagement in the traditional lecture format, especially with pretty dry material.
Although interesting material, very math based (to the point where a lot of the PSet were trying to figure out complex math equations and not actual microeconomic theory).
Yes. I would recommend Intermediate Microeconomics especially if you have interest in business and company relationships on a mathematic level.
I took it for the major, so would recommend for econ majors.
I would recommend this course to all students considering on majoring in Economics, EP&E, or Global Affairs. This is a required course for those majors.
unless for your major def not
I don't think that I would recommend this class, unless you are an econ major and have to take it.
Not unless it's strictly required. I took it only to take more interesting courses in the Econ department later.
Yes. Definitely take it in the spring with Professor Chalioti!

Only if you're really into quantitatively modeling behavior, which is the root of microeconomics/behavioral economics, I guess? For the rest of us, Eva and the TAs tried to help you along as much as they can.
Absolutely not. Very difficult class.
Only makes sense to take it if you are an econ major
it is super hard...be prepared for hard midterm/final...pretty good curve but definitely need to put a lot of work into it.
I would recommend this course to students looking to apply topics in multivariable calculus to social sciences.
Yes, if they can handle the math.

It is a requirement for most people in Econ related majors. If it is not a required course for your major, then I absolutely do not recommend taking it unless you excelled in your previous mathematics and econ classes.

You probably have to take it. As an applied math major who doesn't necessarily have to take it, I kind of regret it because I didn't feel like I learned anything different than intro micro except how to apply the calculus
Only take it if you have to for your major. Otherwise there is nothing to be gained here, I promise you
I thought the class was great. Definitely for logicians and those quick with a calculation.
This course should only be taken by those who need the course for a major requirement, which is pretty much already the case.
Econ and GA majors have to take it...no need if it isn't a major requirement.
It's alright, but don't take it unless you have to.
Yes, the class is very helpful and offers a lot of practical insight.
You are most likely taking this because it's a requirement. If you do, take it in the spring. Professor Chalioti is so much nicer and tries to make it less theoretic.
Only take it if you have to, and take it with Evangelia.

Only would recommend this course if you're taking it for your major requirements. It's notoriously dry and difficult for a reason. If you've made it through Math 120 and don't have any problems with the quantitative side of econ then you'll be in fine shape to do well in this course with minimal work. Problem sets are long and take a few hours but they gave everyone this year 100's as long as they handed something in. First exam was tough because it was a time crunch but the second and final were fine.

Professor Chalioti made the course for me. She is a great professor and I would only recommend the material of this course to another student if also taught by Professor Chalioti because I think that if the lecture quality were not so high it would be extremely difficult to succeed in this course given the weaknesses with the TFs and the difficulty of the problem sets/concepts.
Not helpful if you want to get a grasp of what economics is.
Nope, not unless you have to. And if you have to, find something engaging about it and stick w it.
Dont take unless you have to. Poorly structured. TAs dont care.
no
Not unless you had to.
yes because it teaches you fundamentals of economics
Yes it is a good course
Take it with Chalioti! She's the best.

Yes, but only if you have to take intermediate micro as a requirement. If you have to take the course, make sure to take it in the Spring with Prof Eva Chalioti - she's great and presents the material well.
If you're taking this course, you probably have to. So definitely take it with Evangelia Chalioti. She makes it so you can actually understand the material and do really well.
Yes, I mean you probably need it in the end. Not too useful otherwise as far as I can tell.
If you are interested in economics take this course. I would recommend taking Math 118 or 120 beforehand though.

Having heard "horror stories" about Intermediate Micro, I was apprehensive at first about taking this class. But honestly, take this class with Eva. She is such a great lecturer and cares about her students a lot! Lectures were fairly standard, but Eva is really great at explaining the material and doing sample problems with you on the projected screen so that you get an idea of how to do the math or manipulate the concepts before you start the problem set. The TF team is also really great and definitely a resource I used a lot. All in all, I actually enjoyed taking Intermediate Micro--something I never thought I'd say!
If you're an econ major it's required but if you're not it's alright. good to take if you're considering the major at least.

I would recommend it, but you probably have to take it anyway. I think the class was understandable and I learned a lot. However, the curve was a bit rough because everyone did very well, which is hard in a class with a pre-set curve. 

Prof. Chalioti is super nice and helpful, so that definitely helps. I wish PSets were graded to reward those that really put in effort (and create more of a curve), but hopefully it will not matter.

Despite the difficulty of this class, it is extremely awarding and interesting. The class topic is really great and the help is always there to help you succeed in the class. I would highly recommend this course if you want to challenge yourself and learn about higher level microeconomics.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in microeconomics beyond the surface level exploration in intro micro.

It was a required class for me. Overall, not as bad as people make it out to be. The assignments/exams are hard, but grading is on your side. Definitely take it wth professor chalioti if you can -- she's really great!!!
Yes, if they want to learn about economics
I think this class teaches what could otherwise be boring material in a slightly more interesting way.
If required for the major
Only for Econ major - don't take for fun.
Yes!!! Professor Chalioti is the best professor to take this course with.

Hard but not impossible. Youre prob taking it because its required anyway, so just go to office hours for the psets and do the psets/practice problems for the midterms and you should be fine. Eva is super nice and very good at explaining, so go to class and also look at her PowerPoints for pset answers.
If you are an Econ major you kind of have to take this but otherwise its a beat class
I would only recommend it if you have a strong interest in economics, as the material can get pretty dense early on in the course.
Yes, I thought the material was straightforward.
Highly recommend this course with Professor Chalioti. You will like this course if you like algebra and taking derivatives.

Obviously only take this if you have to. That said, workload is pretty light, and the grading distribution is nice. Eva is a fun, accessible, and enthusiastic instructor. However, the material is somewhat challenging and requires basic fluency in calculus (but mostly just being really comfortable with algebra). I didn't understand a sizable portion of the p-sets, but it doesn't hinder you from getting a fine grade. If you really want to learn the material, however, it will take time.
It's a required course but otherwise no, even if it's listed as a prereq. Teaches you practically nothing.
Yes, it's the gateway to a great major at Yale.

This class doesn't really build upon any philosophical concepts introduced in Intro Micro, it just revisits them with harder math. I took the class because I was required too, and didn't particularly enjoy it.

If you're taking it, it's probably for a requirement. That said, I genuinely enjoyed myself and the class definitely wasn't as hard as people say. Psets are graded for completion and there's plenty of ways to get help. Exams were very straightforward and were more or less based on the psets, so it's not hard to do well if you understand the material. The only thing I would say is that since the class is not super hard, the curve is not going to help you that much.
Yes, I very much liked Professor Chalioti.
Unless you need this for your major, I wouldn't take it. There are much more interesting economics classes.
Yes, definitely! Take it if you understand where conclusions you got in Intro Micro came from.
EVA IS THE BEST!!! Glad I could take it with such an amazing woman and professor :) If you take 121, definitely take it with her. It's a hard course but has actually made me love econ a lot more.
I see no reason to take this course other than for a major.
Yes because it's necessary for majors
If they have to take it, it's fine.
Only to those majoring in econ.
This is a major requirement.

I feel like most people take this because they have to, and if you have to, take it. It's a lot of tedious math and not terribly interesting, but you'll get through it (also the professor and tfs are really nice, so that makes the class a little less work). But if you don't have to, don't do this to yourself

Not unless you have to take itbut even then, I'd consider doing Microeconomic Theory for a more engaging and rigorous theoretical approach. I feel conflicted because Eva is really nice and supportive of her students and cares about us, but I very rarely felt stimulated or engaged by this class, and I didn't feel like I learned a lot on top of my (high school) introductory econ course
Only if required.

I would definitely recommend it to any student who has a decent quantitative background, but not to a student who needs a "big picture" to learn topics well as there is not too much time to describe the real world applications of the conceptual theories and formulas given in class.
YES!! Take with Eva because she really inspires you to put in the work and learn this material. It is also very enjoyable work, believe it or not.

The course is a dismal weeder with little mask of being any else; its assumptions are not only abecedarian, but eschewed by the higher field in which the course would ostensibly place its survivors. There is no skill in its content -- the inexorably long psets, without sufficient in-class explanation and only 'just blindly do this' explanations of tired TAs who cannot singlehandedly repair the teaching deficits of the class, make this class simply a war of attrition. The impossible length of the midterm exams striate students in a way that has nothing to do with understanding (and rewarding those with rote tricks or facility with PDEs that are not a written prerequisite -- pity all those trapped by the course whose reviews you don't see, due to midterm drops).
Yes I would recommend this course. While challenging, I found it very rewarding and interesting.
Not necessarily, but given that it is required for the major I would recommend taking it with Professor Chalioti.
Take this class if you have to take this class.
If you like microeconomics.
ye, especially with Eva
Yes, but they should be prepared for a very quantitative course and should learn the value of collaboration early on!

ECON 121 is essentially an applied calculus course. Having no background in multivariable calculus, this was difficult at first but eventually started to make sense. The problem sets are mostly grunt work, especially the first two, which were pretty brutal. Overall, it was a decent course that most take as a requirement for any of several majors. Take it with Chalioti!
Yes, because it is a requirement for the major.
